title: Opening Day 1
speaker: Justin Ribeiro
description: Welcome! An introduction and overview of the following two days and important announcements.

title: Going from Isolate Apps to Sharable Components
speaker: Josh Crowther
description: This talk will show how the flexibility of web components, coupled with an open source mindset, can help to eliminate the duplication and improve the experience for your users.

title: Components for Content
speaker: Bede Overend
description: How Web Components are perfect for a new era of Web Content. How and why we built Simpla - a collection of Custom Elements for inline editing and Content Management, the difficulties around interoperability and how Web Components helped us overcome these challenges.

title: Adding Handwriting Recognition to your application with Custom Elements
speaker: Pierre-Alban DEWITTE
description: Maybe you have a tablet or event better a tablet with a stylus. Do you know that in 2016 you can just write in a website like on a paper and enjoy nice handwriting recognition? See how it is possible with Custom Elements.

title: Polymer in Practice @ Comcast
speaker: Chris Lorenzo
description: You’ll see how simple and elegant the Polymer library makes building web components. You’ll get to hear how Comcast is building its next generation single page apps using the latest browser APIs and Polymer’s building block model.

title: Universal Web Components
speaker: Jordan Last
description: Applications built from web components can be easy to understand, grow, and refactor, because they are easy to break up into modular and declarative pieces. They work well in the browser, but I believe there is far greater potential if they can begin to spill out of the browser, into the desktop, server, and even embedded applications.

title: A Tale of Creativity, ES2015, and Using Native Components in Production
speaker: Matt Shull
description: A team set out to create a design language for their SaaS products learns what it means to use native Web Components in production. Through battles with ES2015, browser compatibility, and polyfills, to victories of designers using HTML to prototype.

title: But there is no web component for that
speaker: Horacio Gonzalez
description: In this talk I will show how easily you can create a web component wrapping a JS library, allowing you to use it like any other element in your application. And in order to show it, I will take two real life examples.

title: Props Down, Events Up; A Guide to Managing State
speaker: Matthew Phillips
description: State management is currently a big topic in front-end development. Drawing inspiration from the built-in elements we are all already familiar with, we'll discuss the method "props down, events up" and how this approach gives you freedom.

title: Unleashing Production Ready Custom Elements
speaker: Andrea Giammarchi
description: On the 14th of July 2014 I published the first working code for the only Custom Elements polyfill that covered every browser down to IE8. It's 2017 and there are still many untold stories about Custom Elements. In this talk I'll go through what's worked since 2014, the evolution and what's reliable for use today. Live demos and code included.

title: Closing Day 1
speaker: Leon Revill
description: A quick summary of the day and important announcements.

title: Opening Day 2
speaker: Justin Ribeiro
description: An overview of day 2 and important announcements.

title: The eternal sunshine of the biased mind
speaker: Trey Shugart
description: The talk will cover my exploration as a developer and philosophical differences to the populus. The journey to the deep, and back again. Making the right choice vs the popular choice both in open source and my every day job. The present is a misconception of the future and the future is a misconception of the past.

title: Apps with custom elements and RxJS
speaker: Danny Blue
description: In this session learn how to build a simple app using custom elements and RxJS for state management.

title: Beautiful Web Apps with Polymer and TypeScript
speaker: Kito D. Mann
description: In this session you will learn about how to use these technologies together, and how they were used for a real-world IoT project.

title: Why you will probably never author WCs and that's OK
speaker: Raphaël Rougeron
description: Web Components are frequently perceived as an one-size-fits-all approach to front-end development, while they are in fact quite complementary to solutions like React, Angular or Ember when combined properly. We’ll talk about where they really fit in the front-end stack and what we can do as a community so that web developers will never have to author another dropdown anymore.

title: Consuming a REST API in the browser? You don't need routing
speaker: Tomasz Pluskiewicz
description: Routing is the default choice for managing state of SPA web applications. However taking advantage of a well-designed REST API can make it completely obsolete thus simplifying you JS code. And there is an element for that.

title: Getting the basics right: The challenges and payoffs of building general-purpose web components
speaker: Jan Miksovsky
description: In a typical web application, over 50% of the front-end code may reimplement user interface patterns that have already been coded many, many times before. This talk will cover one open source project tackling that challenge.

title: Using Custom Elements in Production
speaker: Thomas Wilburn
description: For the last two years, The Seattle Times has been using custom elements as a standard part of our toolkit. In this talk, I'll discuss our approach, the elements we use, and the advantages we see of building news apps using declarative markup.

title: TBA
speaker: Rob Dodson
description: Talk title to be announced shortly.

title: Closing Day 2
speaker: Leon Revill
description: Summary of the conference and important announcements.
